===Etymology 1===
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
[[File:Grass.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|芝}}: common [[grass]], especially as found in [[lawn]]s.]]
{{wikipedia|Grass}}
{{wikipedia|Lawn}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=しば}}. One of the oldest attested words in the Japanese language, used in the ''[[w:Man'yōshū|Man'yōshū]]'' and ''[[w:Nihon_Shoki|Nihon Shoki]]''.

This character usually means a type of {{m|en|fungus}} in Chinese. However, it was also used phonetically in {{m|ltc|芝麻|tr=*chimæ||sesame}} (modern {{cog|cmn|芝麻|tr=zhīmá}}), and it seems that the Japanese use of this character for the sense of {{m|en|grass}} may have come from this ''sesame'' sense in Chinese.

* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{ja-accent-common|h|し|ば}}<ref name="NHK">{{R:NHK Hatsuon}}</ref>
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[ɕiba̠]}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しば}}

# [[grass]], [[turf]]
#: {{lang|ja|'''芝'''付乃 御宇良佐伎奈流 根都古具佐 安比見受安良婆 安礼古非米夜母。}}<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|14|3508}}; [http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man14Yo.html]</ref>
#: {{ja-usex|'''芝'''付の　御宇良崎なる　ねつこ草　相見ずあらば　我れ恋ひめやも。|'''しば'''つきの　みうらさきなる　ねつこぐさ　あひみずあらば　あれこひめやも。|The anemone flowers on '''grass'''y Miura Point; if we hadn't seen each other, I probably wouldn't be so in love.}}
# short for {{ja-l|芝見||shibami}}: [[hiding]] in the [[grass]] and [[spying]] on one's [[enemies]] or [[scouting]] out the situation; a [[spy]] in the [[grass]]

=====Conjugation=====
{{ja-suru|しば}}

===Etymology 2===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=しざま|し|tr1=shi|pos1=adjectival ending|様|tr2=sama|t2=kind, type}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> {{rendaku2|sort=しざま|sama|zama}} The kanji {{ja-l|芝}} was used as an [[ateji]], probably based on its {{l|ja|sc=Latn|音読み|''on'yomi''}} of ''shi''.

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[ɕiza̠ma̠]}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|しざま}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しざま|grammar|obsolete}} “''shi''-type”, referring to the ''i'' adjective in Japanese grammar, specifically the {{m|ja|ク活用|tr=ku katsuyō||''ku'' inflection}}, corresponding to modern Japanese adjectives ending in ''-i'' but not ''-shii''
#: This is the [[nomenclature]] used in the [[grammar]] devised by {{lang|ja|富士谷成章}} ([[w:Fujitani Nariakira|Fujitani Nariakira]]), a classical Japanese [[scholar]] and [[grammarian]] in the middle [[w:Edo period|Edo period]]. Modern ''i'' adjectives still had the {{m|ja|終止形|tr=shūshikei||terminal form}} ending in ''-shi'' in the mid-Edo period, hence Fujitani's description of these as the “''shi''-type” of adjective.

===Etymology 3===
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=し}} {{m|ltc|芝|tr=*chi}}. Compare modern {{cog|cmn|芝|tr=zhī}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|音読み|On'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[ɕi]}}

====Affix====
{{ja-pos|し|affix}}

# the {{ja-l|万年茸||mannentake}} [[mushroom]]
